description: one of the first two volume in harper eminent live series korda bring his acclaimed storytelle talent to the life of ulysses s grant a man who manage to end the civil war on a note of grace serve two term as president write one of the most successful military memoir in american literature and be today remember as a brilliant general but a fail president ulysses s grant be the first officer since george washington to become a fourstar general in the united states army and the only president between andrew jackson and woodrow wilson to serve eight consecutive year in the white house in this succinct and vivid biography michael korda consider grant character and reconcile the conflict evaluation of his leadership ability grant life play out as a true horatio alger story despite his humble background as the son of a tanner in ohio his lack of early success in the army and assorted fail business venture his unwavering determination propel he through the rank of military leadership and into the presidency but while the general tenacity and steadfastness contribute to his success on the battlefield it both aid and cripple his effectiveness in the white house assess grant both within the context of his time and in contrast to more recent american leader korda cast a benevolent eye on grant presidency while at the same time concede his weakness he suggest that though the general second term end in financial and political scandal the fact remain that for eight year grant exert a calming influence on a country that have only just emerge from a horrendous civil war ulysse s grant be an evenhanded and stirring portrait of a man who guide america through a pivotal juncture in its history

description: charlie asher be a pretty normal guy a little hapless somewhat neurotic sort of a hypochondriac he s what s know as a beta male the kind of fellow who make his way through life by be careful and constant you know the one who s always there to pick up the piece when the girl get dump by the biggertallerstronger alpha male but charlie be lucky he own a building in the heart of san francisco and run a secondhand store with the help of a couple of loyal if marginally insane employee he s married to a bright and pretty woman who actually love he for his normalcy and she rachel be about to have their first child yes charlie do okay for a beta that be until the day his daughter sophie be bear just as charlie exhaust from the birth turn to go home he see a strange man in mintgreen golf wear at rachel hospital bedside a man who claim that no one should be able to see he but see he charlie do and from here on out thing get really weird people start drop dead around he giant raven perch on his building and it seem that everywhere he go a dark presence whisper to he from under the street strange name start appear on his nightstand notepad and before he know it those people end up dead too yup it seem that charlie asher have be recruit for a new job an unpleasant but utterly necessary one death its a dirty job but hey somebodys get to do it christopher moore the man whose lamb serve up jesus miss year with the funny part leave in and whose fluke find the deep humor in whale researcher live now shine his comic light on the undiscovered country we all eventually explore death and dying and the result be hilarious heartwarming and a hell of a lot of fun

title: Thomas Jefferson
description: in this unique biography of thomas jefferson leading journalist and social critic christopher hitchens offer a startlingly new and provocative interpretation of our found father situate jefferson within the context of americas evolution and trace his legacy over the past two hundred year hitchen bring the character of jefferson to life as a man of his time and also as a symbolic figure beyond it conflict by power jefferson write the declaration of independence and act as minister to france yet yearn for a quieter career in the virginia legislature predict that slavery would shape the future of americas development this profess proponent of emancipation elide the issue in the declaration and continue to own human property an eloquent writer he be an awkward public speaker a reluctant candidate he leave an indelible presidential legacy jefferson statesmanship enable he to negotiate the louisiana purchase with france double the size of the nation and he authorize the lewis and clark expedition open up the american frontier for exploration and settlement hitchen also analyze jefferson handling of the barbary war a lesserknown chapter of his political career when his attempt to end the kidnapping and bribery of americans by the barbary state and the subsequent war with tripoli lead to the building of the us navy and the fortification of america reputation regard national defense in the background of this sophisticated analysis be a large historical drama the fledgling nation struggle for independence form in the crucible of the eighteenthcentury enlightenment and in its shadow the deformation of that struggle in the excess of the french revolution this artful portrait of a formative figure and a turbulent era pose a challenge to anyone interested in american history or in the ambiguity of human nature

title: Muhammad

title: Meeting Jesus Again for the First Time
description: of the many recent book on the historical jesus none have explore what the late biblical scholarship mean for personal faith now in meet jesus again for the first time marcus borg address the yearning of those who want a fully contemporary faith that welcome rather than oppress our critical intelligence and openness to the good of historical scholarship borg show how a rigorous examination of historical finding can lead to a new faith in christ one that be critical and at the same time sustain believe in jesus do not mean believe doctrine about he borg write rather it mean to give one heart one self at its deep level to the live lord draw on his own journey from a naive unquestione belief in christ through collegiate skepticism to a mature and contemporary christian faith borg illustrate how an understanding of the historical jesus can actually lead to a more authentic christian lifeone not root in creed or dogma but in a life of spiritual challenge compassion and community in straightforward accessible prose borg look at the major finding of modern jesus scholarship from the perspective of faith bring alive the many level of jesus character spirit person teacher of alternative wisdom social prophet and movement founder he also reexamine the major story of the old testament vital to an authentic understanding of jesus show how an enriched understanding of these story can uncover new truth and new pathway to faith for question believer doubter and reluctant unbeliever alike meet jesus again for the first time free our understanding of jesus life and message from popular misconception and outline the way to a sound and contemporary faith for ultimately jesus be not simply a figure of the past but a figure of the present meeting that jesusthe live one who come to we even nowwill be like meet jesus again for the first time

title: Reading the Bible Again for the First Time
description: one of the vital challenge face thoughtful people today be how to read the bible faithfully without abandon our sense of truth and history read the bible again for the first time provide a muchneeded solution to the problem of how to have a fully authentic yet contemporary understanding of the scripture many mistakenly believe there be no choice other than fundamentalism or simply reject the bible as something that can bring meaning to our life answer this modern dilemma acclaim author marcus borg reveal how it be possible to reconcile the bible with both a scientific and critical way of thinking and our deep spiritual need lead to a contemporary yet ground experience of the sacred text this seminal book show you how to read the bible as it should be examinedin an approach the author call historicalmetaphorical borg explore what the scripture mean to the ancient community that produce and live by they he then help we to discover the meaning of these story provide the knowledge and perspective to make the wisdom of the bible an essential part of our modern life the author argue that the conventional way of see the bible origin authority and interpretation have become unpersuasive to million of people in our time and that we need a fresh way of encounter the bible that take the text seriously but not literally even as it take seriously who we have become borg trace his personal spiritual journey describe for reader how he move from an unquestione childhood belief in the biblical story to a more powerful and dynamic relationship with the bible as a sacred text brim with meaning and guidance use his own experience as an example he reveal how the modern crisis of faith be itself root in the misinterpretation of sacred text as historical record and divine dictation and open reader to a truer more abundant perspective this unique book invite everyonewhatever one religious backgroundto engage the bible wrestle with its meaning explore its mystery and understand its relevance borg show we how to encounter the bible in a fresh way that reject the limit of simple literalism and open up rich possibility for our life

commonplace will human cloning ever be safe be there many universe how much will the climate change during the come century the good american science writing 2002 gather top writer and scientist cover the late development in the fastestchanging farthestreache scientific field such as medicine genetic computer technology evolutionary psychology cuttingedge physics and the environment among this year altruism have a definite place in the evolution of human nature david berlinskis what bring a world into be ponder the idea of biology and physics as essentially digital technology explore the mystery encode in the universe small unit be they cell or quanta nicholas wade show how one of the most controversial book of the year the skeptical environmentalist by former greenpeace member and selfdescribe leftist bjorn lomborg debunk some of the most cherished tenet of the environmental movement suggest that thing be perhaps not as bad as we ve be lead to believe and as a counterpoint darcy frey profile of george divoky reveal a dedicated researcher whose love of bird and mystery lead to some sobering discovery about global warming and forcefully remind we of the unsung hero of science those who put in long hour fill in small detail and take great trouble in the end the unanswered question be what sustain scientific inquiry open new frontier of knowledge and lead to new technology and medical treatment the good american science writing 2002 be a series of exciting report from science front line where what we do not know be every bit as important as what we know

influence on his mature art of the wondrous bag of memory he retain from childhood anais nin describe her sense of word as oppressive explain how imagistic free association free she as a writer add these personal account to laboratory study of thought process johnsteiner take a refreshingly holistic approach to the question of creativity what emerge be an intriguing demonstration of how specific sociocultural circumstance interact with certain personality trait to encourage the creative mind among the topic examine here be the importance of childhood mentor figure the lengthy apprenticeship of the talented person and the development of self expression through highly individualistic language whether in image movement or inner speech now with a new introduction this awardwinning book provide an uniquely broadbase study of the origin development and fruit of human inspiration

title: Ride of the Second Horseman
description: accurst be he that first invent war write christopher marlowea declaration that most of we would take as a literary not literal construction but in this sweeping overview of the rise of civilization robert oconnell find that war be indeed an inventionan institution that arosedue to very specific historical circumstance an institution that now verge on extinction in ride of the second horseman oconnell probe the distant human past to show how and why war arise he begin with a definition that distinguish between war and mere feud war involve group rather than individual issue political or economic goal and direction by some governmentalstructure carry out with the intention of last result with this definition he find that ant be the only other creature that conduct itbattle other colony for territory and slave but ant unlike human be drive by their gene in human change in our culture and subsistencepattern not our genetic hardware bring the rise of organize warfare oconnell draw on anthropology and archeology to locate the rise of war sometime after the human transition from nomadic hunting and gathering to agriculture when society split between farmer and pastoralist around 5500bc these pastoralist initiate the birth of war with raid on middle eastern agricultural settlement the farmer respond by ring their village with wall set off a process of further social development intensify combat and ultimately the rise of complex urban society dependentupon warfare to help stabilize what amount to highly volatile population structure beset by frequent bout of famine and epidemic disease in time of overpopulation the army either conquer new land or selfdestructe leave few mouth to feed in time of underpopulation slave weretaken to provide labor oconnell explore the history of the civilization of ancient sumeria egypt assyria china and the new world show how war come to each and how it adapt to vary circumstance on the other hand society base on trade employ war much more selectively andpragmatically thus minoan crete long protect from maraud pastoralist develop a wealthy mercantile society mark by unmilitaristic attitude equality between man and woman and a relative absence of class distinction in assyria by contrast war come to be an end in itself in aculture dominate by male warrior despite the violence in the world today oconnell find reason for hope the industrial revolution break the old pattern of subsistence war no long serve the demographic purpose it once do fascinating and provocative ride of the second horseman offer a farreache tour of human historythat suggest the ageold cycle of war may now be near its end

title: The Family Idiot
description: with this volume the university of chicago press complete its translation of a work that be indispensable not only to serious reader of flaubert but to anyone interested in the last major contribution by one of the twentieth century great thinker that sartre study of flaubert the family idiot be a tower achievement in intellectual history have never be dispute yet critic have argue about the precise nature of this novel or biography or criticismfiction which be the summation of sartre philosophical social and literary thought in the preface sartre write the family idiot be the sequel to search for a method the subject what at this point in time can we know about a man it seem to I that this question could only be answer by study a specific case sartre discuss flaubert personal development his relationship to his family his decision to become a writer and the psychosomatic crisis or conversion from his father domination to the freedom of his art sartre blend psychoanalysis with a sociological study of the ideology of the period the crisis in literature and flaubert influence on the future of literature while sartre never write the final volume he envision for this vast project the exist volume constitute in themselves a unified workone that john sturrock writing in the observer call a shatteringly fertile digressive and ruthless interpretation of these few cardinal year in flaubert life a virtuoso perfomance for all that this book do to make one reconsider his life the family idiot be less a case study of flaubert than it be a final installment of sartre mythology the translator carol cosman have acquit herself brilliantlyfrederick brown new york review of book a splendid translation by carol cosman sartre call the family idiot a true novel and it do tell a story and eventually reach a shattering climax the work can be describe most simply as a dialectic which shift between two seemingly alternative interpretation of flaubert destiny a psychoanalytic one center on his family and on his childhood and a marxist one whose guide theme be the status of the artist in flaubert period and the historical and ideological contradiction face by his social class the bourgeoisiefredric jameson new york times book review jeanpaul sartre 19061980 be offer but decline the nobel prize for literature in 1964 his many work of fiction drama and philosophy include the monumental study of flaubert the family idiot and the freud scenario both publish in translation by the university of chicago press

description: what be human being like how be knowledge possible what be truth where do moral value come from question like these have stand at the center of western philosophy for century in address they philosopher have make certain fundamental assumptionsthat we can know our own mind by introspection that most of our thinking about the world be literal and that reason be disembody and universalthat be now call into question by wellestablished result of cognitive science it have be show empirically thatmost thought be unconscious we have no direct conscious access to the mechanism of thought and language our idea go by too quickly and at too deep a level for we to observe they in any simple wayabstract concept be mostly metaphorical much of the subject matter of philosopy such as the nature of time morality causation the mind and the self rely heavily on basic metaphor derive from bodily experience what be literal in our reasoning about such concept be minimal and conceptually impoverish all the richness come from metaphor for instance we have two mutually incompatible metaphor for time both of which represent it as movement through space in one it be a flow past we and in the other a spatial dimension we move alongmind be embody thought require a bodynot in the trivial sense that you need a physical brain to think with but in the profound sense that the very structure of our thought come from the nature of the body nearly all of our unconscious metaphor be base on common bodily experiencesmost of the central theme of the western philosophical tradition be call into question by these finding the cartesian person with a mind wholly separate from the body do not exist the kantian person capable of moral action accord to the dictate of a universal reason do not exist the phenomenological person capable of know his or her mind entirely through introspection alone do not exist the utilitarian person the chomskian person the poststructuralist person the computational person and the person define by analytic philosopy all do not existthen what doeslakoff and johnson show that a philosopy responsible to the science of mind offer radically new and detailed understanding of what a person be after first describe the philosophical stance that must follow from take cognitive science seriously they reexamine the basic concept of the mind time causation morality and the self then they rethink a host of philosophical tradition from the classical greek through kantian morality through modern analytic philosopy they reveal the metaphorical structure underlie each mode of thought and show how the metaphysics of each theory flow from its metaphor finally they take on two major issue of twentiethcentury philosopy how we conceive rationality and how we conceive language

title: Exclusion and Embrace
description: life at the end of the twentieth century present we with a disturbing reality otherness the simple fact of be different in some way have come to be define as in and of itself evil miroslav volf contend that if the heal word of the gospel be to be hear today christian theology must find way of speak that address the hatred of the other reach back to the new testament metaphor of salvation as reconciliation volf propose the idea of embrace as a theological response to the problem of exclusion increasingly we see that exclusion have become the primary sin skew our perception of reality and cause we to react out of fear and anger to all those who be not within our evernarrowing circle in light of this christian must learn that salvation come not only as we be reconcile to god and not only as we learn to live with one another but as we take the dangerous and costly step of open ourselves to the other of enfold he or she in the same embrace with which we have be enfold by god be there any hope of embrace our enemy of open the door to reconciliation miroslav volf a yale university theologian have win the 2002 louisville grawemeyer award in religion for his book exclusion embrace a theological exploration of identity otherness and reconciliation abingdon 1996 volf argue that exclusion of people who be alien or different be among the most intractable problem in the world today he write it may not be too much to claim that the future of our world will depend on how we deal with identity and difference the issue be urgent the ghetto and battlefield throughout the worldin the live room in inner city or on the mountain rangestestify indisputably to its importance a croatian by birth volf take as a starting point for his analysis the recent civil war and ethnic cleansing in the former yugoslavia but he readily find other example of cultural ethnic and racial conflict to illustrate his point and since september 11 one can scarcely help but plug the new world player into his incisive description of the dynamic of interethnic and international strife exclusion happen volf argue wherever impenetrable barrier be set up that prevent a creative encounter with the other it be easy to assume that exclusion be the problem or practice of barbarian who live over there but volf persuade we that exclusion be all too often our practice here as well modern western society include american society typically recite their history as narrative of inclusion and volf celebrate the truth in these narrative but he point out that these narrative conveniently omit certain group who disturb the integrity of their happy ending plot therefore such narrative of inclusion invite long and gruesome counternarrative of exclusionthe brutal history of slavery and of the decimation of native american population come readily to mind but more current example could also be find most propose solution to the problem of exclusion have focus on social arrangementswhat kind of society ought we to create in order to accommodate individual or communal difference volf focus rather on what kind of self we need to be in order to live in harmony with other in address the topic volf stress the social implication of divine selfgive the christian scriptures attest that god do not abandon the godless to their evil but give of godself to bring they into communion we be call to do likewisewhoever our enemy and whoever we may be the divine mandate to embrace as god have embrace be summarize in pauls injunction to the romans welcome one another therefore just as christ have welcome you romans 157 susan r garrett coordinator of the religion award say that the grawemeyer selection committee praise volfs book on many count these include its profound interpretation of certain pivotal passage of scripture and its brilliant engagement with contemporary theology philosophy critical theory and feminist theory volfs focus be not on social strategy or program but rather on show we new way to understand ourselves and our relation to our enemy he help we to imagine new possibility for live against violence injustice and deception garrett add that although address primarily to christians volfs theological statement open itself to religious pluralism by uphold the importance of different religious and cultural tradition for the formation of personal and group identity the call to embrace the other be never a call to remake the other into one own image volfwho have just deliver a lecture on the topic of exclusion and embrace at a prayer breakfast for the united nations when the first hijacked plane hit the world trade centerwill present a lecture and receive his award in louisville during the first week of april 2002 the annual religion award which include a cash prize of 200000 be give jointly by louisville presbyterian theological seminary and the university of louisville to the author or originator of creative work that contribute significantly to an understanding of the relationship between human being and the divine and way in which this relationship may inspire or empower human being to attain wholeness integrity or mean either individually or in community the grawemeyer awardsgiven also by the university of louisville in the field of musical composition education psychology and world orderhonor the virtue of accessibility work choose for the award must be comprehensible to think person who be not specialist in the various field

the idea that nonviolent action be passive its important for we to be clear about this there be nothing passive about gandhian nonviolent action I m afraid gandhi himself help create this confusion by refer to his method at first as passive resistance because it be in some way like technique bear that label but he soon change his mind and reject the term gandhis nonviolent action be not an evasive strategy nor a defensive one gandhi be always on the offensive he believe in confront his opponent aggressively in such a way that they could not avoid deal with he but be not gandhis nonviolent action design to avoid violence yes and no gandhi steadfastly avoid violence toward his opponent he do not avoid violence toward himself or his follower gandhi say that the nonviolent activist like any soldier have to be ready to die for the cause and in fact during indias struggle for independence hundred of indians be kill by the british the difference be that the nonviolent activist while willing to die be never willing to kill gandhi point out three possible response to oppression and injustice one he describe as the coward way to accept the wrong or run away from it the second option be to stand and fight by force of arm gandhi say this be well than acceptance or run away but the third way he say be good of all and require the most courage to stand and fight solely by nonviolent mean
